text:
Hi Mo Yes there must be some documentation online that explains these specific errors. Anyway you can still login without the certificate if you want to keep working on your code. Just use the `trading.login_interactive()`  function instead of  the `trading.loogin()` * *function* *and comment out* *`certs=certs_path` in the
```betfairlightweight.APIClient( username=my_username,
password=my_password,
app_key=my_app_key,
#certs=certs_path
)    ```
* *function. See screenshot image attached. Screenshot image is take from: <https://github.com/liampauling/betfair>

text: The error you shared earlier comes from a certificate error. I found it easier to create the certificates with OpenSSL rather than xca as I got these errors when I was using xca to generate certificates. I couldn't find the documentation which stated what the specific error meant, but got enough from google to understand it was certificates causing the problem.

elements.text: The error you shared earlier comes from a certificate error. I found it easier to create the certificates with OpenSSL rather than xca as I got these errors when I was using xca to generate certificates. I couldn't find the documentation which stated what the specific error meant, but got enough from google to understand it was certificates causing the problem.

text: <@UBS7QANF3> In my example that didn't display the prices, it was because I was picking up the market at the point it was created so there were no prices to display. When I force the slider to a more advanced location, the prices for the market_book at that time do show. So this is just a slider / buttons issue.

elements.text: In my example that didn't display the prices, it was because I was picking up the market at the point it was created so there were no prices to display. When I force the slider to a more advanced location, the prices for the market_book at that time do show. So this is just a slider / buttons issue.

Notebooks can be a bit sticky and hang on to old objects unless you explicitly reload them
```from importlib import reload
reload(betfairviz)```

text: Another aside for those new to Colab. You can link it to your Google Drive, which gets around having to keep uploading files - you just drop them all in a drive folder and assess them in Colab as though they were local to the notebook. More details here: <https://www.marktechpost.com/2019/06/07/how-to-connect-google-colab-with-google-drive/>

attachments.title: How to Connect Google Colab with Google Drive
attachments.text: How to Connect Google Colab with Google Drive. In this tutorial, you’ll learn how to connect your Google Colab with Google Drive to build some Deep Learning
